text: [Music]
my talk today is the future of transportation and my i have multiple uh hats that i
wear one is i am a professor of astronautics at the university of southern california where i actually got my masters my phd
um and i am also an entrepreneur and have a company called hydroplane which is focused on sustainable aviation and i do a lot of
other things on the sustainable transportation front amongst other things but in terms of my background
thank you for that kind introduction i am an aerospace engineer all my degrees are in aerospace
engineering my phd actually is in the design and propulsion system so i'm one of you people that actually does get to call myself a rocket scientist
realistically and i worked many years developing technologies in that area i spent most of my career working for
nasa the jet propulsion laboratory focused on robotic space exploration starting with the design of high
efficiency propulsion systems for deep space exploration and then i did something completely
different uh which was working on the entry descent landing system for the curiosity rover and that picture is me in front of the
parachute which was my primary deliverable for that mission i did that for about five years and then
i led the development of an atomic physics facility for the international space station although i didn't have a background in
atomic physics i did have a background of plasma physics for my phd and this was more of a leadership role for me and
that facility is now onboard the international space station it was launched in 2018 and then i decided to leave nasa after
about 16 years because i got recruited to join the high tech transportation sector and i was an
executive at a virgin hyperloop for about two years and then i shifted over to the sustainable aviation space
first co-founding an electric aviation startup focused on electric vertical takeoff and landing which i'll talk about a little
bit later on in the presentation and now focused on energy storage systems for sustainable aviation so my career trajectory has
always been one very much coupled to engineering aerospace engineering technology
and i've tried to increase my role in terms of leadership as i've progressed through my career
because it was important to me for growth as a person as well as being able to make more of an impact when you have that kind of
leadership role so it's been a fun wild ride so far but one of the things which i think is important
when i give presentations is to kind of talk about why i do what i do and i can go back to the space program a
little bit on that front which is understanding your place in the universe so in this graphic on my slide
you can see the three terrestrial planets um on the left-hand side is venus and the middle is earth and on the right
is mars and what's fascinating is that at the formation of the solar system these three planets the terrestrial
planets were really similar to each other in the sense that they did have water on the surface they did have um atmospheres appreciable atmospheres they
were all potentially able to support life but over the course of the past four and a
half billion years these planets have evolved quite differently venus which is one planet in from us has
a surface temperature of 475 degrees centigrade so it's pretty hot that's how you turn
your oven to the self-cleaning temperature it has a surface pressure of 100 atmospheres so 100 times the surface
pressure of earth so no life as we know it can exist on the surface of venus and this planet didn't used to be this
way on the other token mars which is one planet out from us has a surface pressure one percent what
we have here on earth and has a temperature which is quite cold into the you know minus 170 degree centigrade uh regime in the winter time
at night on the surface of the planet so what we can see is that climate change happens at a
planetary scale and it can be a planetary phenomena so by sending spacecraft and rovers and
landers to visit these other planets we can actually understand more about our own planet and how we can protect it and how it might evolve in the future
so i think that's really important because we can see how space exploration actually does tie into our goals here on earth for
sustainability in that very important scientific way but i am an engineer by training
my father was an engineer as well one of my favorite quotes is that science is the study of what is and engineering basically creates the
world um that you want to exist so using engineering using the principles of math and science you can create technologies
to solve the world's problems i think it captures it quite well and from a entrepreneurial aspect
engineers are also inventors and we need to only go back you know over just over 100 years with the wright brothers
where they did the first demonstration of lifting body powered flight and even before they did that
demonstration in the late 1800s very famous scientists including lord kelvin who's very famous on the
physics side said heavier than air flying machines that's not possible so sometimes you really do have to think
outside the box um and you can't just listen to what other people are doing what other people say is gonna work you really have to
listen to yourself and believe in your own ideas and make those become a reality and of course uh now that we have powered flight it's
changed our world tremendously and that did start not that long ago and it changed our society significantly so
a lot about me though comes from my childhood and that is being a massive science fiction fan
so i'm a huge fan of written science fiction as well as television science fiction you know star trek probably i grew up on
that um watching that with my dad and kind of what i think is so fascinating about science fiction is
that it shows you an alternate view of the universe there of course is dystopian science fiction but there's also a lot of utopian science fiction
like star trek for example and it shows you that you can have this amazing universe where people are exploring and
using science um and not thinking and focusing on wars for example at least a portion of it so
the engineer ultimately can make science fiction a reality and when it comes to the technologies
that we develop it means that we can literally build the future that we imagine and we see that with you know the flip phones
that exist in motorola that came in the early 2000s they were kind of invented in a sense in star trek as well as
tablets were invented in star trek and a lot of the technologies even my phd ion drive which is what i did my phd and of course
is what power is the enterprise so it is very inspiring to be able to take these messages of a better world
from science fiction and then make it as part of your career which is essentially what i've tried to do so i want to talk a little bit about how
technology has changed the world but focused more on the transportation space and i think it's a great parallel
because go back many thousands of years 3000 bc the invention of the wheel as far as we
know you know from the archaeological record originally developed for ceramic purposes but then developed for
transportation purposes and having the wheel really did revolutionize human society because now
you're able to move around people and goods at a much faster pace over longer distances consuming less energy so it allowed
human society to grow and to flourish move forward several thousand years beyond that
the industrial revolution was actually enabled by um the the train right so being able to
once again move around goods and people over vast differences uh relatively efficiently in
terms of how much food you have to eat to walk those distances and allowing human society to expand
from villages into towns and into cities move forward another couple of decades internal combustion engine
the invention of personal mobility with the car now one could make all kinds of arguments that the car is not a good
thing uh but nevertheless we can talk about that later in the q and a section but obviously we have been able to
harness that technology to produce um personal transport which has enabled uh city expansion and personal mobility
and then of course probably i would say the most impactful transportation innovation was the aircraft because
air travel enables global connections and commerce on time scales which are an order of magnitude reduced from what
they were before that if not more so you can really see how technology has changed human society in terms of its
growth as well as economic growth because with each one of these new technologies think about how society grew and how
different um you know ecosystems came about as a result of that so it's pretty profound in that way but when we think about
transportation we also have to think about uh the wastes associated with it um one of them of course is related to
congestion so more people more transport more congestion so right now if we take a look at any port around
the world you'll see that they're congested certainly in la which is where i live which means that goods and services
aren't able to get around as efficient as they like to if you take a look at the freeways in any major city anywhere in the world
they're super congested and if you take a look at cargo on the road that couples to that congestion so what we're seeing is uh right now we're
kind of at the limit of what our existing transportation system can handle and that's why we're experiencing all this congestion
and because of the use of internal combustion engines and fossil fuels that also translates to poor air quality
and it also translates to climate change with the production of co2 so we do need to come up with a
sustainable transportation system both from the congestion perspective as well as from the uh minimizing our
use of fossil fuels perspective and sadly i think most people who are in these spaces are not
sort of innovators which means they keep on looking at more of the same bigger airports more rail lines more high-speed rail
lines more trucks wider highways and that doesn't really address the problem which is the fact that this mode is kind of at its capacity so
in the face of overwhelming odds um you're left with only one option this is mark watney from the book and the movie the martian which is to
science the out of it it's a great quote um i think it's kind of inspiring and entertaining at the same time but you can use science and
engineering to solve these challenges if you understand what your requirements are so ultimately
we do need to reinvent transportation and when we think about reinventing transportation we have to think about what the ultimate end user of that
transportation wants and that end user can be the government or the you know governmental entity which is paying for
it um or it can be the end user who's actually going to ride on that system and hopefully there are two interests are intertwined
probably the most important one for the person who travels is reducing travel time nobody likes to
sit in traffic nobody likes to move around slowly um that also couples to a good passenger experience in terms of it being
comfortable and entertaining and then when you look at it from a city planning perspective or transportation planning perspective
you think about capacity how many people do i need to move around per hour per year between these two points between those
two points that's where capacity comes in and turn that into an engineering metric and then we also have to think about
safety so one of the big focuses of anybody who's developing a transportation system is to ensure that
it meets current safety standards and also is safer than other modes of transportation
because why on earth would you not want to improve yourself right and so we're going through great lengths to ensure that all new technologies that
come in especially on the autonomy front are safe and actually can improve safety overall for passengers and for drivers and for
the pedestrian public cost is also important if something's too expensive it's never going to happen
both in terms of the cost to develop the infrastructure behind a transportation system as well as the cost of the person who's
going to go off and buy a ticket and any transportation system if it's a mass transportation system has to be affordable to everybody
otherwise by definition it won't work and i think one of the biggest goals that we'll see now finally as a world because the u.s is
going to come back on board with climate agreements is environmental impact so
transportation does make up a large percentage of the co2 which is produced by us as a species so if we can
reduce the carbon emissions and eliminate the carbon emissions that become carbon neutral with our transportation systems that
goes a long way to helping reduce the environmental impact of human society and
when we think about transportation systems we shouldn't just think about this local city that we're living in we have to think about our state
our country our continental landmass so all transportation systems have to be scalable so they can interoperate
with other types of transportation systems and ultimately connect more people so what are some of the new
transportation systems that are out there in the future well the first one not everybody knows about it but i think a lot of people do
now because it's kind of um it's developed its own meme huh this is the beam which is elon musk
so back in 2013 elon musk baby very famous aerospace entrepreneur now
in the united states um put out a white paper to challenge california's ballot measure
which was to fund a high-speed rail system it came out i think in 2008 um sort of the
the proposition idea to do it and then he said why do you want to go off and spend all this money a billion dollars
on a transportation system which is old technology not very efficient not very environmentally friendly why not do
something which is more efficient like the hyperloop so what is the hyperloop um well the hyperloop is a new form of
green transportation i'll talk about that in a second but this is kind of the the background story of the california high-speed rail
project which has cost a lot of money it's terribly behind schedule it's over budget and it's essentially been scaled back from what was
originally proposed for those reasons so in a sense elon musk was right by pointing that out but the hyperloop
wasn't invented by elon musk it actually came from science fiction so for any of you who've watched this 1960s
era cartoon about the jetsons which is the picture of the guy traveling in the tube at a fast speed that was kind of a version of the
hyperloop and there's some other graphics from science fiction from the 1960s in the 1970s who proposed the
hyperloop as a form of modern transportation in the future uh cities of um you know planet earth and
perhaps other even other planets so what is the hyperloop um i can describe it uh in a very simple way
it's very similar to a maglev train so you have passenger cars like a matlab train does that are magnetically levitated so you
don't get friction along the track and then they're electrically propelled using a linear electric motor
what's different about the hyperloop from a maglev train is that the passenger cars are inside of a vacuum
tube and the reason why that's important is because if you can remove the air from around the passenger car
you eliminate essentially aerodynamic drag an aerodynamic drag is your primary energy consumption as
you go up in speed because it scales with the speed squared so if you take out the air from around the vehicle you're basically like a
spacecraft traveling on the ground you accelerate yourself up to speed you coast like a spacecraft would within the tube and
then you slow down when you get to your stop so it allows it to operate at airline speeds and even greater but with very
little energy consumption because of that reduction in aerodynamic drag you did an initial pump down in the vacuum tube you make it pump down
and then um you don't open it up unless you have to for you know servicing or some other type of reason and the passenger vehicles themselves
are kind of like an airplane but without wings because they have to be pressurized to protect the people inside
um and they have to be lightweight obviously because they have to lift off the ground using this electromagnetic
levitation but it is a feasible concept um i actually worked as an executive at
a hyperloop technology company for two years we built a hyperloop i'll show you a picture of that in a second um but the question of course people
will ask and should ask is well so why are we not building these awesome hyperloops everywhere there's a reason it's incredibly
expensive so any ground-based infrastructure project is you know more than 10 billion u.s dollars more
than 10 billion euros for example so it's very hard to be able to get a government to pay for something that expensive
when the technology is so new so that's ultimately the reason why we're not seeing hyperloops uh you know just being built
left and right because it has high cost as well as high technology risk and so that's where technology companies can come in and
solve that problem um and so most of the companies who are working in this space are startups so they're entrepreneurial
ventures run by small teams um and they're able to operate cost effectively because they're so small versus a big you know corporate
entity with a lot of overhead so you can have a lot of technology innovation coupled to the entrepreneurial spirit couple to the
venture capital world to potentially bring about this transportation solution around the world which is more
friendly so there are technology startups working on the hyperloop in europe there's probably a pretty famous one called
heart which is up in the netherlands i met those guys before really cool guys when i was working for mine which was
hyperloop one um we were looking at ways that we could collaborate with other hyperloop companies so
one of the things that startups do really well is that they prototype new technology and so they're able to do that relatively
quickly and cost effectively and so for the company that i worked for which you can see me standing in front of the vacuum tube
we actually built a hyperloop so there is a half a mile long hyperloop in the desert just outside of las vegas up until very
very recently it was just a technology demonstration test bed so we would move the capsule um in it to these speeds accelerate it and
then decelerate it and that was all you could do but there was recently a test where they put people inside of it which was done for technology demonstration purposes
but the passenger car you can see represented in the upper left there where you would sit inside that and move along that tube from one station to the
next station um all developed using cutting edge material technologies to enable a
reduction in weight which enables a reduction in operational cost at the end of the day but there are more than one company around there
there's another one in los angeles ironically but they're pretty much popping up all over the world now so now the question is which country will have their first
hyperloop but one of the things where i like to see connections is how different industries
can actually leverage different technologies to work together and so because the hyperloop has to operate at really fast speeds
basically in excess of airline speeds you can't have a traditional trade operator stop and start stop and start
it has to be done autonomously and so um a suite of technologies that already exist or at least are in
development is in the autonomous car driving industry which can be leveraged to be put into
the source of transportation systems either ground-based hyperloop to give autonomy to them or even in the air for aerial
transportation which i'll talk about next but ultimately we can use these technologies associated with autonomy
whether that's machine learning or artificial intelligence to create the safe environment of autonomy to avoid
hazards and the really easy thing about the hyperloop of course is that there are very few hazards because you're traveling inside of a tube so you don't
have the traditional problem of other cars uh pedestrians animals and things like that because
ultimately there is nothing other than the car which is in front of you so it's a easy way to implement something like
this for autonomy into a mass transportation system and the way that you make this affordable is by having really good
ridership so if you have a lot of people filling up this system every single hour of every single day then all of a sudden you can
over amortize the cost of that development and increase uh price or decrease price and they increase ridership and then the other goal behind
the hyperloop is that it's not going to be a big long train car with 50 cars it's going to be smaller pods which are
running more frequently which makes it more close to an on-demand type of system like a subway
almost as opposed to the traditional train that you might take to go long distances but then again autonomy of course is the
key because of the speeds at which it's operating but a lot of can be leveraged from the existing um automotive sector so when is the
hyperloop coming um it's always coming soon so someone does have to sign on and put up the money to develop one of these systems
it may be that it happens in a middle eastern country first because they have more capital to put towards
their transportation infrastructure it's hard to say but i know there's certainly interest in the united arab emirates
there's also interest in india so it's really more an issue of how much money is going to be set aside
but all of the studies are underway as to how to implement it into an existing transportation system
how much footprint do you need to be able to lay out the track um what kind the power requirements are but remember because it's an
electrically propelled system it can operate off grid based power so that if that grid-based power is coming from
renewables this can actually be a carbon neutral mass transportation system solution so
we can definitely have more questions in the q a about how it works and challenges because i know that's always of interest to people but i enjoyed my
time working on it and ultimately i'm the kind of person who likes to work on something for five
years create something and then do something else because the hyperloop is a very expensive proposition i didn't see it
happening in five years it's probably not going to happen in 10 years and so for me i wanted to then move on we did the technology

instrument rated i'm currently working on my commercial rating and i'm also a disaster relief pilot so for me flying

flying cars so although i'm not specifically talking about a car which flies which is it drives in the road and flies i am
talking about moving around in highways in the sky as opposed to highways on the ground and the current movement for urban air
mobility which is air taxis is to have fully electric aircraft which are traveling
in airways in the sky above cities and above urban environments on a fully electric platform and the
reason why that's important is because electric aviation currently relies on batteries batteries are very very heavy
which means that these aircraft are also very very heavy and they can only travel short distances so because
of the reliance on batteries which we're trying to do to get this technology going we're limited to use cases which only go
short distances basically less than 100 kilometers less than 60 miles but because there is a potential use

so this is very different from what you would experience in one of these air taxis because they're low capacity

these smaller platforms and that's ultimately the reason why but if you can find a use case for these platforms which is air taxis
then you can see how there is a a way to get this going and there's certainly other use cases with regards to cargo transport with regards to

to the tech sector in terms of the mobility as a service market so
uber for example has a program called uber elevate where they're actually creating a set of requirements

with aircraft because of their internal combustion engines is incredibly expensive so shifting to electric platform actually reduces

and it can be completely green and when we think about the hyperloop we already have the vacuum tube you
